subject: Psychology
title: The Activation-Synthesis Model
description: A quick win: understand The Activation-Synthesis Model.

hook.text: What if dreams mean nothing? What if the brain just fires randomly and your mind scrambles to make a story?

buildup.text: Hobson and McCarley proposed the activation-synthesis model: dreams result from random brainstem signals during REM.

discovery.text: The cortex receives these random signals and synthesizes them into a narrative â€” creating dreams from neural noise.

twist.text: Critics argue dreams aren't fully random. Emotional themes recur, and dream content connects to waking concerns.

climax.text: The model showed dreams have a biological basis. But meaning isn't absent â€” the brain imposes order on chaos.

punchline.text: Dreams may start as noise. The mind makes them stories.

quiz.question: What does the activation-synthesis model propose?
options: Dreams result from the brain making sense of random signals
Dreams are messages from the unconscious
Dreams perfectly replay the previous day
